On Wednesday 07 July 2004 10:49 pm, Curt Sampson wrote:
>  On Tue, 6 Jul 20=
04, hedgi wrote:
>  >=A0=A0 Now I there is the problem. I want to run "test=
Common" first
>  >=A0=A0 which is in the "BasicGetListTest" but when I subc=
lass it with
>  >=A0=A0 "GlucoseGetListTest" it is always executed last. I =
read some of
>  >=A0=A0 the postings in this newsgroup, but it seems that s=
uch kind of
>  >=A0=A0 requirement point a desing flaw and I should somehow=
 rearrange my
>  >=A0=A0 Unit Test Structure to made the tests indepentdant=
. I'm stuck with
>  >=A0=A0 it.
>
>  I've been thinking for a while that th=
is is a serious problem in JUnit
>  (and most unit testing frameworks), bec=
ause it's been such an annoyance
>  for so many people. Let's face it; a lo=
t of groups of tests do have
>  known dependencies between tests such that =
if test A fails, we know that
>  the output of tests B, C and D are uninter=
esting. Yet we end up running
>  B, C and D anyway, and then searching thro=
ugh all the error output for
>  the failure that we know is the "real" one,=
 ignoring all the others as
>  spurious.

With all due respect, I believe t=
hat is a code smell.  It seems to say to me 
that there is something not ri=
ght about the design of the code being tested, 
or perhaps even more elusiv=
e, something is wrong with how the tests are 
written.  When I find these t=
ypes of dependencies I inevitably rethink how I 
have written my tests.  Ha=
ve I coded in the dependencies or are they really 
there.  More times than =
not I have coded in the dependencies -- and therefore 
I can remove them.  =
Further, I would argue that I _NEED_ to remove them.  
Now, maybe I am old-=
fashioned but I believe tests (at least at the 
unit/programmer level) ough=
t to be as autonomous as possible.
